column1: Rio Grande do Norte/São Gonçalo do Amarante–Governador Aluízio Alves International Airport (IATA: NAT
column2: ICAO: SBSG) is an airport in São Gonçalo do Amarante
column3: Brazil serving Natal and its metropolitan area.The airport is administrated by Consortium Inframérica.

column1: Governador Aluízio Alves International Airport is a new airport complex in São Gonçalo do Amarante
column4: built to replace Augusto Severo International Airport.

column1: Planning for the airport started in 2007 envisioning concepts of an intermodal airport
column2: focusing both on passenger and cargo transportation. The complex is expected to have the highest aircraft traffic in the Northeast.On May 12
column4: the National Civil Aviation Agency of Brazil (ANAC) released a document opening the concession of the airport to private entrepreneurs. The auction to choose the winner took place on August 22
column5: 2011. The winner was an Inframérica Consortium
column6: formed by the Brazilian Engineering Group Engevix (50%) and the Argentinean Group Corporación América (50%).After the signature of the contract of concession
column7: works of the passenger and cargo terminals started. Inframérica Consortium had 3 years to build the terminals and is authorized to commercially explore the facility for 25 years (with one possible 5-year extension). Differently from other Infraero airports in process of privatization
column8: in which Infraero retains 49% of the shares
column9: in the case of Natal Consórcio Inframérica got 100% of the shares. On February 6
column10: 2012 Consortium Inframérica also won the concession of Brasília–Presidente Juscelino Kubitschek International Airport.The airport was opened for operations on May 31
column12: when airlines moved their domestic operations to this facility. International operations were moved a few days later. The airport is the first airport in Brazil operated by a private sector company.

column1: The airport is located 25 km (16 mi) from downtown Natal.
